· just now. Report Abuse. A primary cause of skin cancer is damage to DNA by ultraviolet radiation. In normal skin, the pigment or melanin present serves as a natural sunscreen, absorbing much of the UV radiation and preventing it from damaging the DNA of skin cells. In albinos, they lack the ability to make melanin. As such, their DNA is much more susceptible to UV damage and skin cancer. The best prevention is to stay out of the sun. Use of clothing and/or sunscreens can also effectively limit sun exposure. Source(s): Ph.D.

Albinos lack skin and eye pigments, including melanin. Melanin absorbs energy from the sun, which protects skin cells from damage to DNA that the energy would cause if the melanin is not there. Introduction. Albinism affects the production of melanin, the pigment that colours skin, hair and eyes. People with albinism have a reduced amount of melanin or no melanin at all, which can cause characteristic signs and symptoms often obvious from birth. Depending on the amount of melanin the person has, they may have very pale hair, skin and eyes, although some people with albinism can have brown or ginger hair and skin that can tan. albinism. [al′biniz′əm]. a rare inherited disorder characterized by a lack of melanin in the skin. Total albinos have pale skin that does not tan, white hair, pink eyes, nystagmus, astigmatism, and photophobia. Albinos are prone to severe sunburn, actinic dermatitis, and skin cancer. albinism. a hereditary disorder, usually transmitted as an autosomal recessive trait, in which there is partial or total absence of pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes (oculocutaneous albinism) or in the eyes alone (ocular albinism), caused by defective or absent function of the enzyme tyrosinase.

Albinism is associated with a number of vision defects, such as photophobia, nystagmus and amblyopia. Lack of skin pigmentation makes for more susceptibility to sunburn and skin cancers. Most skin cancers are caused by exposure to the sun. There are 2 main types of non melanoma skin cancer, basal cell carcinoma (BCC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). A history of sunburn increases the risk of BCC. Risk is especially high if you had several episodes of sunburn in childhood.
